newsitem.title: GERMANY: GERMAN CALL MONEY EASES BELOW 3.10 PERCENT.
newsitem.headline: GERMAN CALL MONEY EASES BELOW 3.10 PERCENT.

text.p: German call money rates continued to ease on Thursday, trading as low as 3.07 percent after changing hands in a range of 3.10 to 3.125 percent on Wednesday.
Dealers said rates eased because of a rise in money market liquidity, reflected in higher bank deposits at the Bundesbank.
"The deposit figures caused call money to fall below 3.10 percent," one money dealer at a large German bank said.
Commercial banks' deposits at the Bundesbank rose to 41.5 billion marks on Wednesday from 41.0 billion.
While call money rates eased, the rate on longer-term funds tightened because the Bundesbank's August monthly report had heightened fears of an increase in interest rates, dealer said.
The 12- month Frankfurt Interbank Offered Rate (Fibor) climbed to 3.58958 percent from Wednesday's 3.56600 percent.

The Bundesbank uttered strong words on inflation in its report, saying it could not be overlooked that there had been a stronger rise in consumer prices in the last few months and that it would orientate its policy in such a way that price stability can be maintained.

The Frankfurt Interbank Overnight Average (FIONA) was 3.11133 percent, down from 3.12933 percent. Average bank deposits at the Bundesbank for the month through Wednesday were 40.0 billion marks, up from 39.8 billion.
